questions.text: Which of the following is true about pterygium?

options.label: C
options.text: Conjunctival invasion making a flap over cornea

questions.correct_answer: C. Conjunctival invasion making a flap over cornea
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer C - Conjunctival invasion making a flap over cornea

Pterygium/Surfer’s eye

 

 

 

 

 

 

Definition

Pterygium is a triangular encroachment of vascularized granulation tissue covered by conjunctiva in the interpalpebral area.

  • Parts: Cap, head, neck, body
  • Degenerative process

 

Aetiology

  • Common in dry, sunny climates with sandy soils
  • Ultraviolet light is a probable factor
  • Usually elderly persons

 

 

 

 

 

Pathology

Histology shows collagenous degenerative changes in the vascularized subepithelial stroma.

 

 

Pathogenesis

  • Degenerative subconjunctival proliferation
  • Granulation tissue proliferates as avascularized tissue encroaches on the cornea.
  • Destroys the superficial layers of the stroma and Bowman’s membrane

 

 

 

Symptoms

  • Frequently follows a pinguecula
  • Often bilateral
  • Usually on the nasal side
  • Impairment of vision due to:
    • Progression into the pupillary area of the cornea
    • Induced astigmatism by corneal flattening in the axis of pterygium
  • Progressive pterygium: thick and vascular
  • Regressive pterygium: thin, pale, and atrophic
  • Ceases to grow but never disappears
  • A probe can be passed under the lesion
  • Can present as inflammed pterygium

Signs

  • A probe cannot be passed under the lesion
  • Fusch’s spots/Islets of Vogt: small discrete whitish flecks made of pterygial epithelial cells seen in progressive pterygium and are also called the cap of the pterygium.
  • Stocker line: linear epithelial iron deposition, seen in regressive pterygium.

 

 

 

Management

  • Best left alone

Medical treatment:

  • Tear substitutes for small regressive pterygium with dry eye
  • Topical steroids for associated inflammation
  • Protection from UV rays with sunglasses

Surgical excision for:

  • Progression of lesion towards the pupillary area causing excessive astigmatism and visual impairment
  • Restricted ocular movements
  • Disfiguring
  • Diplopia

 

 

Procedures
  • Bare sclera technique:
    • The pterygium is excised from the cornea and conjunctiva, leaving a bare sclera
    • Associated with a high recurrence rate
  • Autoconjunctival graft
    • A piece of limbal conjunctival tissue from the same or the other eye or
    • An amniotic membrane graft is used to cover the bare sclera
    • Sutured at the limbus to cover the defect
  • Surgical excision with lamellar keratectomy and lamellar keratoplasty for deeply infiltrating recurrent recalcitrant pterygia
  • Old methods (not used now):
    • McRaynold’s operation
    • Postoperative use of beta irradiations

 

Post-operative therapy and care
  • Prevent recurrence:
    • Mitomycin C 0.02% drops
    • Complications like scleral necrosis, cataracts, and iritis

Pseudopterygium

Definition

  • Pterygium like lesion
  • Due to cicatrizing conjunctival inflammatory overgrowth

 

 

Aetiology

  • Seen at any age
  • Caused by
    • Trauma
    • Chronic conjunctivitis
    • Thermochemical burn

 

Symptoms

  • Non-progressive
  • Can be at any quadrant of the corneal limbus
  • Located away from the horizontal
  • Attached to the cornea due to scar tissue
  • Adhered to the adjacent lid
  • Always stationary

Signs

  • A probe can be passed under the neck.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 23-year-old male who has been experiencing eye pain, sensitivity to light, and redness for the last two days, following an injury caused by brushing his eyes against leaves and thorns while gardening?
questions.explanation:
Etiology
  • Causative organism: Aspergillus fumigatus >> Fusarium
  • Predisposing factor: Vegetative matter injury (trauma) (Option C)

Clinical Features
  • SIGNS >> symptoms
  • Pain & Foreign Body Sensation
  • Watering/ Photophobia
  • Blurred Vision, Redness

Examination Findings
  • Corneal Ulcer: Greyish-white, dry, elevated, rolled-out margins
  • Pigmented Ulcer: Brownish, dematiaceous fungi
  • Feathery Extensions: Finger-like projections in stroma
  • Sterile Immune Ring: Yellow line of demarcation
  • Satellite Lesions: Small lesions around the main ulcer
  • Hypopyon: Large, immobile, non-sterile, even in small ulcer
  • Perforation: Rare but possible

Investigations
  • Corneal Scraping: For microbiological examination
  • Wet KOH Mount: Filamentous fungi or yeast-like fungi (Candida)
  • Culture: Sabouraud's agar for fungal culture
  • PCR: For rapid identification of pathogens
  • Corneal Biopsy: For deep stromal abscess or negative cultures

Treatment
  • Topical Antifungal Agents: Natamycin 5%, Voriconazole, Amphotericin-B, Nystatin
  • Oral Antifungal Agents: Ketoconazole, Voriconazole (for severe ulcers)
  • Surgical Management:
    • Repeated Scraping: Removal of necrotic material
    • Cauterization Options: Carbolic acid (100%), Trichloroacetic acid (10%–20%), Povidone-iodine (5%)
    • Therapeutic Keratoplasty: Corneal transplantation

 

BACTERIAL KERATITIS (Option B)

FUNGAL KERATITIS

Etiology
  • S. aureus (worldwide)
  • S. epidermidis (India)
  • Aspergillus

Examination Findings
  • Fluorescein stain positive ulcer
  • Hypopyon (sterile)
  • Stromal edema
  • Descemet’s membrane folds
  • Keratic precipitates due to anterior uveitis
  • Signs >>> symptoms
  • Dry/rough ulcer
  • Has projecting ends
  • Thick immobile unsterile hypopyon
  • Satellite nodules are infective and have immune reaction- Wessley ring
  • IOP is high

Treatment
  • Empirical monotherapy: Moxifloxacin, gatifloxacin, besifloxacin
  • Duo therapy: Gram positive + gram negative. Combination of Cefazolin with Gentamicin or Cefuroxime with Gentamicin.
  • Cycloplegics and mydriatics
  • Antifungals: Natamycin 5%, amphotericin B
  • Steroids are contraindicated

questions.text: In the image provided, which refractive error is observed in the depicted condition?
questions.explanation:
Description
  • Progressive, non-inflammatory bilateral ectatic corneal condition affecting the axial part.

Pathology
  • Involves progressive thinning and ectasia of the cornea due to defective synthesis of mucopolysaccharides and collagen.

Clinical Features
  • Defective vision due to progressive myopia and irregular astigmatism (uncorrectable by glasses) (Option B)
  • Blurred and distorted vision, glare, and halos around lights
  • Light sensitivity and ocular irritation
  • Visual loss primarily from irregular astigmatism and myopia, secondary loss from corneal scarring

Examination Findings
  • Distorted Window Reflex: Visual irregularity on corneal reflection.
  • Placido Disc Irregularity: Irregular circles.
  • Slit-Lamp Examination:
    • Thinning and ectasia of the central cornea.
    • Opacity at the apex, Fleischer Ring (brownish ring around the cone due to haemosiderin in the epithelium).
    • Folds in Descemet's and Bowman's membranes.
  • Vogt Striae: Fine, parallel striae at the apex, disappearing with external pressure.
  • Oil Droplet Reflex: Annular dark shadow separating central and peripheral cornea in distant direct ophthalmoscopy.
  • Retinoscopy: Yawning reflex (scissor reflex) with high oblique/irregular astigmatism.
  • Ophthalmoscope Findings: Irregular astigmatism and progressive myopia, poorly corrected by glasses in later stages.
  • Munson's Sign: Localized bulging of the lower lid when looking down (seen in late stages).
  • Keratometer Findings: Malformed, malaligned, and malfocused mires.
  • Corneal Topography: Sensitive method for early detection, shows corneal surface shape.

Management

Spectacle Correction:

  • Effective in the early stages, but contact lenses are more beneficial.
  • Less effective in later stages due to irregular astigmatism.

Contact Lenses:

  • Rigid gas permeable lenses improve vision in early cases.
  • Specially designed scleral lenses (e.g., Rose-K) are useful in early to moderate cases.

Corneal Collagen Cross-Linking (CXL):

  • New treatment modality to slow disease progression.
  • Involves Riboflavin (0.1%) eye drops and UVA radiation.
  • Riboflavin induces cross-linking of corneal collagen to stabilize the stroma and improve contact lens tolerance.

Keratoplasty :

  • Recommended if disease progresses or in cases of acute hydrops (Descemet's membrane tear).
  • Reserved for more advanced diseases or when other treatments fail.
  • Penetrating keratoplasty is common, but Deep Anterior Lamellar Keratoplasty (DALK) is preferred if Descemet's membrane and endothelium are intact, reducing rejection risk.

Intracorneal Ring Segments (INTACS) :

  • Effective in early to moderate cases by flattening the cornea.
  • Less effective in halting progression.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the corneal epithelium?

options.label: A
options.text: Regeneration is limited to the limbus

questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - Bowman’s membrane regenerates

Layers of Cornea

Epithelium

 
  • The outermost layer comprises 5-6 layers of non-keratinized, stratified squamous epithelial cells.(Option C ruled out)
  • Acts as a barrier, protecting the cornea and preventing tear fluid from entering the underlying stroma.
  • Outermost layer Apical cells have microvilli to move the tear fluid.(Option D ruled out)
  • The basal cells at the limbus are stem cells responsible for regenerating the corneal epithelium.

Bowman’s Membrane

 
  • Located just beneath the epithelium, this acellular layer is 12 µm thick and composed of densely packed collagen fibrils.
  • It is a protective barrier to the stroma but cannot regenerate (Option B) if damaged and heals by scarring.

Stroma
  • Making up about 90% of the cornea's thickness (approximately 0.5 mm thick), the stroma consists of collagen fibrils arranged in parallel layers.
  • These fibrils are embedded in a hydrated matrix of proteoglycans - Chondroitin and Keratan Sulphate (keratan sulphate maintains corneal transparency).

Pre-Descemet's Membrane (Dua's Layer)
  • This layer, discovered in 2013, is about 15 µm thick, acellular, and lies just above Descemet's membrane.
  • It is strong and resistant to air penetration.

Descemet's Membrane
  • A robust basement membrane of the corneal endothelium is made of collagen and glycoproteins.
  • It is tense, but when torn, curls inwards on itself.
  • It can regenerate (Option A ruled out) if damaged and is resistant to trauma and pathological processes.

Endothelium

 
  • The innermost layer consists of a single layer of flat, hexagonal cells.
  • These cells are crucial for maintaining corneal transparency by regulating fluid balance within the cornea through an active pump mechanism.

questions.text: Which layer is accountable for preserving the moisture and clarity of the cornea?
questions.explanation:
Layers of Cornea

Epithelium

(Option D ruled out)
  • The outermost layer comprises 5-6 layers of non-keratinized, stratified squamous epithelial cells.
  • Acts as a barrier, protecting the cornea and preventing tear fluid from entering the underlying stroma.
  • The basal cells at the limbus are stem cells responsible for regenerating the corneal epithelium.

Bowman’s Membrane
  • Located just beneath the epithelium, this acellular layer is 12 µm thick and composed of densely packed collagen fibrils.
  • It is a protective barrier to the stroma but cannot regenerate if damaged and heals by scarring.

Stroma

(Option C ruled out)
  • Making up about 90% of the cornea's thickness (approximately 0.5 mm thick), the stroma consists of collagen fibrils arranged in parallel layers.
  • These fibrils are embedded in a hydrated matrix of proteoglycans - Chondroitin and Keratan Sulphate (keratan sulphate maintains corneal transparency).

Pre-Descemet's Membrane (Dua's Layer)

  • This layer, discovered in 2013, is about 15 µm thick, acellular, and lies just above Descemet's membrane.
  • It is strong and resistant to air penetration.

Descemet's Membrane (Option A ruled out)
  • A robust basement membrane of the corneal endothelium is made of collagen and glycoproteins.
  • It is tense, but when torn, curls inwards on itself.
  • It can regenerate if damaged and is resistant to trauma and pathological processes.

Endothelium

(Option B)
  • The innermost layer consists of a single layer of flat, hexagonal cells.
  • These cells are crucial for maintaining corneal transparency by regulating fluid balance within the cornea through an active pump mechanism.

questions.text: What is the distinguishing characteristic of a fungal ulcer?

options.label: B
options.text: Dendritic ulcer on a fluorescein dye

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman with a history of trauma to the left eye 5 days back now presented with complaints of complete loss of vision. Upon examination the following findings were seen. What should be the subsequent course of action to manage this condition?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Keratoplasty

 

Optical
  • Corneal opacity
  • Bullous keratopathy
  • Corneal dystrophies
  • Advanced keratoconus

Therapeutic

To replace an inflamed cornea that does not respond to conventional therapy

Tectonic Graft

To restore the integrity of the eyeball, e.g., after corneal perforation (Option A) or in cases of significant corneal thinning.

Cosmetic

To improve the appearance of the eye

questions.text: Which glycosaminoglycan is responsible for the transparency of the cornea?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Keratan sulfate

Mucopolysaccharide

Primary Locations

Functions

Hyaluronic Acid (Option B)

Connective tissues, tendons, synovial fluid, vitreous humor

Serves as a lubricant in joint cavities and contributes to the structure of connective tissues

Heparin (Option C)

Liver, lungs, spleen, monocytes

Acts as an anticoagulant by activating antithrombin III, which inactivates thrombin and other clotting factors

Chondroitin Sulfate

Cartilage, bone, tendons, cornea, skin

Provides structural support to connective tissues and contributes to their resilience and elasticity

Keratan Sulfate (Option A)

Cornea, cartilage

 

Dermatan Sulfate (Option D)

Skin, blood vessels, heart valves

Contributes to the structure of the skin, blood vessels, and heart valves

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 30-year-old man who has a previous history of wearing contact lenses, and is currently experiencing pain, redness, and the presence of pus coming from his right eye? During examination, a greyish-white ulcer in the shape of a snake was observed on the lower portion of the cornea. Additionally, a hypopyon measuring 4 mm was found in the anterior chamber, along with a moderate flare reaction.
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - Bacterial corneal u

questions.text: A patient sustained blunt trauma to the eye 6 months ago and now presents with blurring of vision. What is the most likely condition?
For which of the subsequent diseases is collagen cross-linking therapy utilized?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Keratoconu

questions.text: What's the main risk for a 37-year-old man with blurred vision and severe pain in his right eye? He revealed that recently, he went swimming in a pond. During examination, a ring-like lesion was found, as seen in the image.
questions.explanation: Correct Option D - Soft C

questions.text: What is the diagnosis for a female patient, aged 65, who has a history of chickenpox and presents at the clinic with the following findings?
questions.explanation: Correct Option C - Herpes zoster ophthalmicu

questions.text: Arlt’s line is seen in?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Trachoma

Signs of active trachoma

Signs of cicatricial trachoma

Conjunctival signs:

  • Conjunctival congestion
  • Follicles in the upper tarsal conjunctiva: Look like sago-grains
  • Papillary enlargement: red, velvety

Conjunctival signs:

  • Scarring
    • It may be irregular, star-shaped, or linear
    • Linear scar in the sulcus subtarsalis is called Arlt’s line (Option C)
  • accumulation of dead epithelial cells and inspissated mucus in the glands of Henle
  • Pseudocyst
  • Xerosis
  • Symblepharon

Corneal signs:

  • Superficial keratitis on slit lamp and fluorescein
  • Herbert’s follicles
  • Progressive pannus/Trachomatous pannus: The upper part of the cornea is cloudy
  • Corneal ulcers are common at the advancing edge of the pannus
    • Shallow, little infiltrated
    • Cause lacrimation and photophobia

Corneal signs:

  • Regressive pannus or pannus siccus:
    • Receding infiltration
    • Vessels extend beyond the area of infiltration and haze
  • Herbert pits: oval or circular pitted scars formed after the healing of Herbert’s follicles in the limbal area
  • Vascularized and opaque cornea.
  • Corneal xerosis
  • Corneal ectasia
  • Total corneal pannus (blinding sequelae)

 

 

Lid signs:

  • Distortion of the lids
  • Tylosis : Thickening of the tarsal plate/lid margin
  • Trichiasis due to rubbing of lashes on the cornea
  • Trachomatous ptosis (sleepy appearance)
  • Entropion
  • Madarosis
  • Ankyloblepharon

Lacrimal apparatus sequelae:

  • Chronic dacryocystitis
  • Chronic dacryoadenitis

Active Trachoma

 

Follicles in upper palpebral conjunctiva

 

Trachomatous pannus

Progressive pannus

Cicatricial

Trachoma

​​​​​​

 

 

Regressive pannus

 

Conjunctival concretions

 

Trichiasis

Tylosis (thickening of tarsal border of eyelid)

questions.text: What is the main underlying factor responsible for regular astigmatism when studying the optics of a patient?
questions.correct_answer: A. Abnormal curvature of the cornea
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Abnormal curvature of the cornea

Type

Description

With-the-Rule (WTR)

The vertical meridian has greater curvature than the horizontal meridian.

Against-the-Rule (ATR)

The horizontal meridian is more curved than the vertical meridian.

Oblique Astigmatism

Principal meridians are at oblique angles (e.g., 45° and 135°), still perpendicular to each other.

Bi-oblique Astigmatism

Principal meridians are not perpendicular to each other (e.g., 30° and 100°).

Type

Description

Simple Astigmatism

One meridian focuses on the retina; the other focuses in front (simple myopic) or behind (simple hypermetropic).

Compound Astigmatism

Both meridians focus light either in front (compound myopic) or behind (compound hypermetropic) the retina.

Mixed Astigmatism

One meridian focuses in front of the retina (myopic), and the other behind (hypermetropic).

Arlt’s line is seen in which condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Option D - Trach

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presents to the ophthalmology clinic with a history of eye trauma with vegetative material .He complains of severe eye pain, redness, tearing, and photophobia. Microscopic examination of the corneal scraping reveals septate hyphae at an acute angle. What is the most likely causative agent responsible for this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Fungal Corneal Ulcer

questions.text: A corneal wisp test was performed, and the corneal reflex was elicited. Which of the following nerves is responsible for the afferent limb of this reflex?
questions.explanation:
Reflex

Afferent Nerve

Efferent Nerve

Accommodation

II (Optic nerve)

III (Oculomotor nerve)

Corneal

V₁ (Ophthalmic, nasociliary branch)

Bilateral VII (Facial nerve, temporal branch - orbicularis oculi)

Cough

X (Vagus nerve)

X (Vagus nerve, also phrenic and spinal nerves)

Gag

IX (Glossopharyngeal nerve)

X (Vagus nerve)

Jaw Jerk

V₃ (Mandibular branch, sensory from masseter)

V₃ (Mandibular branch, motor to masseter)

Lacrimation

V₁ (Ophthalmic branch) (loss of reflex does not preclude emotional tears)

VII (Facial nerve)

Pupillary

II (Optic nerve)

III (Oculomotor nerve)

questions.text: A patient presents with eyelid crusting and a thready sensation between the cornea and lids. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Definition

Chronic infection of the anterior part of the lid margin

Synonyms

  • Chronic anterior blepharitis
  • Staphylococcal blepharitis

Causative Organisms
  • Most commonly Staphylococci (coagulase positive)
  • Rarely Streptococci, Propionibacterium acnes, and Moraxella

Clinical Features
  • Chronic irritation
  • Itching
  • Mild lacrimation
  • Gluing of cilia
  • Mild photophobia
  • Yellow crusts at the root of cilia
  • Small ulcers that bleed easily when crusts are removed
  • Red, thickened lid margins with dilated blood vessels
  • Mild papillary conjunctivitis and conjunctival hyperemia

Treatment
  • Lid Hygiene:
    • Warm compresses
    • Cotton buds dipped in dilute baby shampoo or 3% sodium bicarbonate solution
    • Avoid touching
  • Antibiotics
  • Topical Steroids
  • Ocular Lubricants

questions.text: A patient presents with redness, extreme eye pain, and diminished vision. The patient frequently wears contact lenses. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for her condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Option C – Acanth

questions.text: Shield ulcer is seen in which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Vernal keratoconjunctivitis or Spring catarrh

It is a recurrent bilateral conjunctivitis that tends to occur with the onset of warm weather. It primarily affects young children and adolescents, particularly boys.

Course

The condition typically starts in childhood and may resolve on its own over 5–10 years.

Symptoms

Burning, Itching, Photophobia (sensitivity to light), and lacrimation (excessive tearing).

Signs
  • Palpebral Form: Hypertrophied palpebral conjunctiva with a cobblestone appearance; bluish-white color; dense fibrous tissue with thickened epithelium.
  • Limbal or Bulbar Form: Opacification at the limbus, gelatinous thickening, and Horner–Trantas dots
  • Pseudogerontoxon/cupid’s bow (which resembles arcus senilis) is a grayish-white ring at the limbus seen in severe limbal vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC).
  • Shield ulcers are a significant complication of VKC, particularly in severe cases. These microerosions typically form on the upper third of the cornea.
  • Mixed form: Exhibits characteristics of both the tarsal (palpebral) and limbal subtypes, typically presenting in only one eye.

Maxwell Lyon's sign is a pseudomembrane formed due to excessive mucus deposition on the papilla resulting in cobblestone papillae.

Histology

In the palpebral form, hypertrophied papillae are observed, rich in eosinophils and other inflammatory cells.

Treatment
  • Topical therapy:
    • Antihistamines - Levocabastine & emedastine
    • Mast cell stabilizers - Sodium cromoglicate
    • Mild steroids - Fluorometholone and loteprednol etabonate,
    • Acetylcysteine can control excess mucus.
  • Local therapy: Subtarsal steroid injections and cryotherapy for severe cases.
  • Surgical treatment: Excision of giant papillae and treatment of shield ulcers with debridement and amniotic membrane or bandage contact lens.
  • Cold compresses and tinted glasses for comfort.
  • Avoid eye rubbing

questions.text: Which of the following layers is associated with the beaten bronze appearance?

A 40-year-old male patient, who works in an iron factory, presents to the clinic with complaints of visual disturbances. He reports that his vision has been gradually worsening and he has noticed a change in the color perception. On examination, the ophthalmologist observes the presence of iron deposits in the eye. What is the most likely ocular condition responsible for the iron deposits in the eye and the patient's visual disturbances?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Siderosis bulbi

questions.text: Which of the subsequent options does not exhibit a characteristic of keratoconus?

A 30 year old man presents with a history of injury to the eye caused by a leaf 5 days ago, resulting in pain, photophobia, and redness of the eye for 2 days . Upon examination, corneal ulcer with feathery ends and satellite lesions around it are seen. What would be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Fungal corneal u

 

Bacterial Corneal Ulcer

Fungal Corneal Ulcer

Viral Corneal Ulcer

Causative Agents

Bacteria (e.g., Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus pneumoniae)

Fungi (e.g., Aspergillus, Fusarium)

Herpes simplex virus (HSV), Varicella-zoster virus (VZV)

Clinical Features

Redness, pain, discharge (mucopurulent), blurred vision, corneal ulcer and sterile hypopyon.

Dry/rough white or grayish-white ulcer with feathery edges, satellite nodules and an unsterile hypopyon.

Dendritic (branching) pattern on fluorescein staining, foreign body sensation, tearing, photophobia

Risk Factors

Trauma, contact lens wear, ocular surface disease, recent ocular surgery

Prolonged corticosteroid use, immunosuppression, ocular trauma or injury with plant material or contaminated objects

Prior history of herpetic infection, immunosuppression, stress, decreased immune function

questions.text: Assertion: Topical steroids should not be used in the treatment of viral corneal ulcers. Reason: Topical steroids can cause increased intraocular pressure What is the correct option ?

options.label: B
options.text: Both assertion and reasoning are independently correct and reason is not correct explanation of the assertion

options.label: C
options.text: Assertion is independently a correct statement, but the reason is false

options.label: D
options.text: Both assertion and reason are false

questions.correct_answer: B. Both assertion and reasoning are independently correct and reason is not correct explanation of the assertion
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - Both assertion and reasoning are independently correct and reason is not correct explanation of th

questions.explanation: Correct Option D

questions.text: Keratometer is used to assess
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Curvature

questions.text: What is the diagnosis ?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D - Keratoconu

Signs of keratoconus

Early signs
  • High irregular /asymmetric astigmatism
  • Scissor’s reflex on retinoscopy
  • Fleischer's ring

  • Vogt's striae

Late signs
  • Munson's sign: Lower lid notching on down gaze
  • Acute hydrops

  • Prominent corneal nerves (due to corneal thinning)

questions.text: What is the likely reason for a 21-year-old student to have ocular redness, feeling of a foreign object in the eye, and excessive tearing after wearing a soft contact lens, as indicated by the corneal scraping interface contrast microscopy image?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Acanth

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 27-year-old male patient who experiences eye trauma from vegetative matter, and currently exhibits symptoms including a corneal ulcer, hypopyon, satellite lesions, mild pain, photophobia, and redness?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Fungal k
